items.content:
Welcome new students! Welcome to the digital way of learning English here at St. Aloysius. First we will see what you already know, then we will learn new things together. We will practice listening, reading, writing and speaking in every theme. You will also learn grammar and vocabulary.

Happy learning!

Here you will learn how to introduce yourself in English.

You will learn how to talk about your hobbies.

You will learn how to ask somebody for information about themselves.

We will also pay attention to the present simple (onvoltooid tegenwoordige tijd).

You will read a short text and be able to understand the text.

You will have a conversation about introducing yourself.

You will listen to a text about somebody talking about themselves.

You will learn about different countries, nationalities and languages.

You will listen to 3 texts about people talking about themselves. After listening, you will answer some questions about the audio (texts). Lastly, you will listen to a text about multiculturalism.

Write your answers in your notebook.

You will need your Students' Book page 6 exercise 1 and 3.

You will need your Students' Book page 8 exercise 7.

You will need your Students' Book page 10 exercise 2 and 3.

Multiculturalism exercise: Complete the sentences.

Multiculturalism ________________. As the world gets smaller, multiculturalism becomes bigger. ________________ live in towns in which there is only one culture. Today, ________________ where we are surrounded by many other cultures. If we live in a city, ________________ from all over the world. Of course, some cities are more multicultural than others. New York is a ________________. It is called the most multicultural city on Earth. A city like Tokyo isn't so multicultural. I think multiculturalism ________________. It's fantastic walking out of your door and seeing other cultures. This didn't happen ________________. People didn't understand other cultures. They didn't ________________ understand. I'm glad things are changing today.

You will read a short text and be able to understand the text.

You will need your Students' Book page 12 for the text. After reading do exercise 1,2 and 4. Write the answers in your notebook.

You will need your Students' Book page 14 for the text. After reading do exercise 2 and 3. Write the answers in your notebook.

Exercise 2: Introductions


Good morning, I would like to introduce myself. My name is David Johnson and it is nice to meet you. I live in a small village that is close to the city of Cambridge. I am 20 years old. I am studying History at university and work in a shop at the weekends. I have one brother and one sister. They are both older than me. My sister is 26 years old and my brother is 22 years old. They have both graduated from university and work in London.

Good morning. Please let me introduce myself to you. I am Hamid and I come from Pakistan. My home town is Islamabad, the capital city. I am 19 years old and have come to the UK to study English. I will stay here for one year. I want to learn a lot. My family is big. I have 3 brothers and 1 sister. I am the oldest and my sister, the youngest, is 11 years old. My father works as a government official and my mother is a housewife. I want to learn English so I can get a good job. I do not work as I spend all my time studying.

Read the text and determine which of the following statements are true. If false, explain why.

  1. David Johnson lives in Cambridge city.
  2. David is studying Science at university.
  3. Every day David works in a shop.
  4. David has a younger brother and an older sister.
  5. David's brother and sister also have jobs.
  6. Hamid comes from India.
  7. Hamid is in England to study History.
  8. Hamid will stay in England for less than one year.
  9. Hamid is the youngest child of the family.
  10. Hamid needs to learn English to work with his father.

Here you will learn about the present simple .

We will also remember the irregular verbs: to be, to do and to have. Irregular means that they do not follow the regular rules. You will have to learn these verbs by heart.

There are youtube videos about this at the bottom of the page.

After watching the video, you will do a few exercises to practice the present simple. You need to write your answers in your notebook or if your teacher has printed it out for you, then you can write on the hand-out.
You will need your Language Builder for more exercises. Your teacher will tell you which exercises you need to do for more practice. You will write these answers in your notebook.

introduction.body: Here's the first exercise

content.body:
1. (read) she reads
  2. (think) he
  3. (fly) it
  4. (dance) he
  5. (have) she
  6. (finish) it

questions.label: Write these verbs with -s or -es

introduction.body: Here's the second exercise

content.body:
1. he the piano.
  2. they in a very big house.
  3. she a lot of fruit.
  4. he tennis.
  5. we to the cinema a lot.
  6. she seven hours a night.

questions.label: Complete the sentences with one of these verbs: eat, go, live, play and sleep.

introduction.body: Here's the third exercise

content.body:
1. Maria four languages.
  2. The shops in the city centre usually at 9 o'clock in the morning.
  3. The City Museum at 5 o'clock in the evening.
  4. Tina is a teacher. She mathematics to young children.
  5. My job is very interesting. I a lot of people.
  6. Peter's car is always dirty. He never it.
  7. Food is expensive. It a lot of money.
  8. Shoes are expensive. They a lot of money.
  9. Water at 100 degrees Celsius.
  10. Laura and I are good friends. I her and she me.

questions.label: Complete sentences. Use the correct form ofthese verbs: boil, close, cost, cost, like, like, meet, open, speak,teach and wash.

introduction.body: Here's the fourth exercise

content.body:
1. (always/ early/ Sue/ arrive)
  2. (to the cinema/ never/ I/ go)
  3. (work/ Martina/ hard/ always)
  4. (like/ chocolate/ children/ usually)
  5. (Jackie/ parties/ enjoy/ always)
  6. (often/ people's names / I/ forget)
  7. (TV/ Sam/ watch/ never)
  8. (usually/ dinner/ we/ have/ at 7.30)
  9. (Kate/ always/ nice clothes/ wear)

questions.label: Write sentences from these words. Use the right form of the verb (arrive or arrives etc.)

values.value: I never go to the cinema

introduction.body: Here's the fifth exercise.

content.body:
1. The weather here is usually nice. It doesn't rain much.
  2. Paul has a car, but he it very often.
  3. Paul and his friends like films, but they to the cinema very often.
  4. Amanda is married, but she a ring.
  5. I much about politics. I'm not interested in it.
  6. The Regent Hotel isn't expensive. It much to stay there.
  7. Ed lives very near to us, but we him very often.

questions.label: Complete the sentences. All of them are negative. Use (don't/ doesn't) + these verbs: cost, go, know, see, use and wear.

introduction.body: Here's the sixth exercise.

content.body:
1. (where/ live/ your parents) Where do your parents live?
  2. (you/ early/ always/ get up) ?
  3. (how often/ TV/ you/ watch) ?
  4. (you/ want/ what/ for dinner) ?
  5. (like/ you/ football) ?
  6. (your brother/ like/ football) ?
  7. (what/ you/ do/ in your free time) ?
  8. (your sister/ work/ where) ?
  9. (breakfast/ always/ you/ have ?
  10. (what/ mean/ this word) ?
  11. (in winter/ snow/ it/ here ?
  12. (go/ usually/ to bed/ what time/ you) ?

questions.label: Make questions from these words + ( do/does). Put the words in the right order.

values.value: Do you always get up early
How often do you watch TV
What do you want for dinner
What do you do in your free time
Does it snow here in winter
What time do you usually go to bed

items.content:
A personal email.
You are going to write an email to your new pen pal from London.
Use the following prompts:

  • Say hello to your new pen pal (think of a name).
  • Write what your name is.
  • Tell where you come from.
  • Give information about your family, parents, brothers or sisters.
  • Tell something about your hobbies.
  • Ask about his or her hobbies.
  • End your e-mail.

You will have a conversation about introducing yourself. You will ask somebody for information about themselves. You will also talk about your hobbies.

Persoon A Persoon B
1 Groet. 1 Groet terug.
2 Vraag hoe oud je gesprekspartner is. 2 Geef antwoord in een volledige zin.
3 Vraag wat je gesprekspartner in zijn/haar vrije tijd doet. 3 Geef antwoord in een volledige zin.
4 Vraag om meer informatie over zijn/haar hobby. 4 Geef antwoord in een volledige zin.
5 Vraag over zijn/haar buurt. 5 Geef antwoord in een volledige zin.
6 Stel een zelfbedachte vraag passend bij de thema. 6 Geef antwoord in een volledige zin.
7 Beëindig het gesprek. 7

Reageer en sluit af.

Change roles and do the speaking exercise again.

Here we will learn about family.

We will also pay attention to the present continuous.

We will learn words about different family members.

You will learn how to ask somebody about their family.

We will also pay attention to the present simple (onvoltooid tegenwoordige tijd) and the present continuous.

You will read a short text and be able to understand the text.

You will have a conversation about your family.

You will listen to a text about a family.

Lottie
Lottie is ten years old.
She lives in England with her father and sister.
She speaks about her father.

Go to this link: http://learnenglishkids.britishcouncil.org/en/short-stories/my-dad

Fill in the worksheet (your teacher might print this out for you)

Mothers exercise: Complete the sentences. Write the answers in your notebook.

Mothers are the people __________________. We all have a special relationship with our mother. We are __________________ our mother.

We spend nine months growing inside her and she is the person __________________ when we are babies. Our mother does everything for us.

She feeds us, cleans us, __________________, treats our cuts and bruises, supports us and loves us. And all __________________.

Mothers still do motherly things even when we are old and __________________. It is very sad to hear that someone's mother has died. I

remember this happening to some children __________________ school. I can't imagine how children grow up without a mother. I hope my mother lives forever. __________________.

She deserves to.

You will read 3 short texts then answer questions about the text. Write the answers in your notebook.

Exercise 1:

You will need your Students' Book page 10 exercise 2,3 and 4.

Exercise 2:

You will need your Students' Book page 16 exercise 1,2 and 3.

Exercise 3:

You are going to read a story about Mary's life.

Mary is ten years old. She is from Dorset. Her hair is long and brown. She has got brown eyes.
She has got a cat and a dog. Their names are Pat and Fluffy. Pat, the dog has got a small house in the garden.
Mary's cat, Fluffy is three years old.
Mary's mother is Jane. She is a teacher. She's thirty-six years old. Jane's hair is blonde and her eyes are brown. Jane hasn't got a pet.
She has a friend. Her name is Laura.
Her husband is Nick. He is thirty-eight. He's a bus driver. He has got brown hair and blue eyes. Nick has got a horse. Its name is Lightning. Nick's friends are bus drivers. They are Tom, Charles and John.
Jane and Nick have got three children: Mary, Sean and Peter.
Sean is six and Peter is twelve years old. The children are pupils.
Sean's hair is blonde, Peter's hair is brown. The boys have got blue eyes.
Peter's pet is a hamster. Its name is Tiny. She is so small.
Sean has got a goldfish. Its name is Goldie.

Are the following statements true or false? If false, explain why.

  1. Mary has got a spider.
  2. Mary's mother is 38 years old.
  3. Nick is Sean's father.
  4. Sean has got a sister.
  5. Mary has got two brothers.
  6. Tiny is a horse.
  7. John is a bus driver.
  8. Tom is Peter's friend.
  9. Fluffy is a cat.

Here we will learn about the present continuous. We will also learn the difference between the present simple and present continuous.

There are youtube videos about this at the bottom of the page.

After watching the video, you will do a few exercises to practice the present continuous. You need to write your answers in your notebook or if your teacher has printed it out for you, then you can write on the hand-out.

items.caption: Verschil present simple en present continuous

items.content: You will need your Language Builder for more exercises. Your teacher will tell you which exercises you need to do for more practice. You will write these answers in your notebook.

introduction.body: Here's the first exercise.

content.body:
1. Please be quiet. I 'm working OR am working.
  2. 'Where's John?' 'He's in the kitchen. He
  3. 'You on my foot.' 'Oh,I'm sorry.'
  4. Look! Somebody in the river.
  5. We're here on holiday. We at the Central Hotel.
  6. 'Where's Sue?' 'She a shower.
  7. They a new hotel in the city centre at the moment.
  8. I now. Goodbye.

questions.label: Complete the sentences. Use these verbs: build, cook, go, have, stand, stay and swim.

introduction.body: Here's the second exercise

content.body:
1. (is/ working/ Ben/ today) Is Ben working today?
  2. (what/ the / children/ are/ doing) ?
  3. (you/ are/ listening/ to me) ?
  4. (where/ your friends/ are/ going) ?
  5. (are/ watching/ your parents/ TV) ?
  6. (what/ Jessica/ is/ cooking) ?
  7. (why/ you/ are/ looking/ at/ me) ?
  8. (is/ coming/ the bus) ?

questions.label: Make questions from these words. Put the words in the right order.

values.value: Why are you looking at me

header.title: Present continuous or Present simple exercise 1

introduction.body: Here's the first exercise (present continuous or present simple).

content.body:
1. Excuse me, do you speak English?
  2. 'Where's Kate?' 'I know.'
  3. What's funny? Why you laughing?
  4. 'What your sister do?' 'She's a dentist.'
  5. It raining. I want to go out in the rain.
  6. 'Where you come from?' 'Canada'.
  7. How much it cost to stay at this hotel? Is it expensive.
  8. Steve is a good tennis player, but he play very often.

questions.label: Complete the sentences with (am/is/are) OR (do/don't/does/doesn't).

header.title: Present continuous or present simple exercise 2

introduction.body: Here's the second exercise (present continuous or present simple).

content.body:
1. Excuse me, do you speak (you/ speak) English?
  2. 'Where's Tom?' ' (he/have) a shower.'
  3. (I/ not/ watch) TV very often.
  4. Listen! Somebody (sing)
  5. Sarah is tired. (she/ want) to go home now.
  6. How often (you/ use) your car? Every day?
  7. 'Excuse me, but (you/ sit) in my seat. ' Oh, I'm sorry.'
  8. I'm sorry, (I/ not/ understand). Can you speak more slowly?
  9. It's late. (I/ go) home now. (you/come) with me?
  10. What time (your father/ finish) work every day?
  11. You can turn off the radio. (I/ not/ listen) to it.
  12. Where's Paul? In the kitchen. (he/ cook) something.
  13. Mark (not/ usually/ drive) to work. He (usually/walk).
  14. Sue (not/ like) coffee. (she/ prefer) tea.

questions.label: Put the verb in the present continuous or present simple.

items.content:
Exercise 1:

Create you own family tree
Je gaat nu zelf een stamboom maken.
Om inspiratie op te doen kan je afbeeldingen googlen.
Gebruik de zoekterm: family tree.

  • Neem een groot vel papier en teken daarop je eigen stamboom.
  • Probeer zoveel mogelijk personen in je stamboom te zetten.
  • Schrijf bij de personen de Engelse familietermen.
  • Schrijf in een aparte kolom welke personen niet in je eigen stamboom voorkomen.
  • Maak bij elk persoon een tekening of plak een foto.
  • Vertel een klasgenoot over je stamboom.

Exercise 2:

An email about your family.
You are going to write an email to your pen pal from New York.
Use the following prompts:

  • Say hello to your pen pal (think of a name).
  • Write about your family.
  • Give information about your mother (what does she look like, age, work ?)
  • Give information about your father (what does he look like, age, work ?)
  • Tell something about your brothers and/or sisters.
  • Think of two questions you could ask your pen pal.
  • Ask your pen pal to write about his/her family.
  • End your email.

You will talk about your family. You will ask somebody about their family.

Exercise 1:

Persoon A Persoon B
1 Groet. 1 Groet netjes terug.
2 Vraag de naam van de ander. 2 Geef antwoord.
Vraag de naam van de ander.
3 Geef antwoord. Vraag hoeveel broers de andere heeft. 3 Geef antwoord. Vraag hoeveel zussen de ander heeft.
4 Geef antwoord. Vraag waar de grootouders van de ander wonen. 4 Geef antwoord in een volledige zin. Vraag waar andere familieleden van de ander wonen.
5 Geef antwoord. 5 Stel een zelf bedachte vraag passend bij het thema.
6 Geef antwoord. Stel nu ook een zelfbedachte vraag passend bij het thema. 6 Geef antwoord in een volledige zin.
7 Beëindig het gesprek. 7 Reageer en sluit af.

Exercise 2:

Persoon A Persoon B
1 Groet. 1 Groet terug.
2 Vraag de naam van de ander. 2 Geef antwoord in een compleet zin.
Vraag de naam van de ander.
3 Geef antwoord in een complete zin. Vraag hoe zijn/haar gezin is samengesteld. 3 Geef antwoord in een complete zin. Vraag hoe het gezin van de ander is samengesteld
4 Geef antwoord in een complete zin. Vraag of hij/zij een grote familie heeft - en uit welke personen die bestaat. 4 Geef antwoord in een compleet. Vraag de ander of hij/zij
veel vrienden heeft en of ze die vaak zien, wat ze samen doen.
5 Geef antwoord in een complete zin. 5 Stel een zelf bedachte vraag passend bij het thema.
6 Geef antwoord in een complete zin. Stel nu ook een andere zelf bedachte vraag. 6 Geef antwoord in een complete zin.
7 Beëindig het gepsprek. 7 Reageer en sluit af.

Here you will learn about jobs, food and drink.

You will learn how to talk about different jobs, food and drinks.

You will learn how to ask somebody for their preferences in food and drinks.

We will also pay attention to the genetive, possessive adjectives and possessive pronouns and countable/uncountable nouns.

You will read a short text and be able to understand the text.

You will have a conversation about jobs, food and drinks.

You are going to listen to audio fragments. While listening, you will need to do the exercises for audio fragments. Your teacher might print out the worksheets for you. Write the answers in your notebooks.

You will need your Students' Book page 17 exercise 5.

You will need your Students' Book page 23 exercise 5.

Snacks exercise: Complete the sentences

Are you a snacker? Can ____________________ meals without a snack?

I'm terrible. I ____________________ - all day long. I know it's bad for me, but snacks are just so delicious.

I have different snacks ____________________ the day. In the mornings, I need energy, so I snack a lot on chocolate and chocolaty snacks.

In the evenings, I'm ____________________ something salty or savory. I love potato chips (or crisps), especially Pringles.

I also cannot stop eating nuts. ____________________ for cashews, macadamia nuts and dry-roasted peanuts.

Luckily, ____________________ on any weight, even though I eat snacks all day.

I reckon it's ____________________ me.

I'll wait until I'm a little older and then cut down on ____________________ I eat.

Qualifications exercise: Complete the sentences

Qualifications are __________________ days. Many years ago, a university degree was enough.

A B.A. or B.Sc. __________________ a good job. Not now.

Not even a Master's degree is enough these days. It __________________ a Master's degree. Some of the jobs I want now require a Ph.D.

It's also not enough nowadays __________________ the qualifications you have.

You __________________ qualifications up to date, re-qualify, get new qualifications.

It seems life has __________________ certificate chase.

Especially so now that many people will have several careers in their life.

I know someone __________________ in physics, then became an accountant, didn't like it and studied to be a lawyer.

He's now studying __________________ license!

Exercise 1: You will need your Students' Book page 22 and 23 exercise 3 and 4.

Exercise 2:

Men don't eat enough vegetables!
Most men don't eat enough fruit and vegetables. Every day you should eat five to ten servings of fruits and vegetables. Only 20 percent of men and 40 percent of women eat enough fruit and vegetables.
What is a serving? A serving can be a small potato, one half cup of a vegetable, one half cup of juice, or a piece of fruit - like an apple.
Why should you eat fruits and vegetables? We need the vitamins, minerals, and fibre that these foods give.
Fruits and vegetables can reduce the risk of cancer, heart disease, and stroke.
Cancer and heart disease kill more than 120.000 Canadians every year.

Bron: www.thewclc.ca

Read the text and determine which of the following statements are true. If false, explain why.

  1. Men eat more fruit and vegetables than necessary.
  2. A serving of fruit and vegetables is a complete meal.
  3. You should eat in between five and ten servings of fruit and vegetables a day.
  4. The vitamins, minerals and fibres we get from food are important.
  5. Fruit and vegetables can help against cancer, heart disease and stroke.

Exercise 3:

911

Sara Lewis is a 911 operator. She is responsible for answering the phone when people call 911. People call 911 when there is an emergency, which can be a fire, a traffic accident, or a medical emergency. People who are 911 operators, like Sara, have to work hard and carefully, because sometimes people's lives depend on their help.

Processing 911 calls is more complicated than you might think. When you call the number, the operator asks your name, your telephone number, and your address. As an operator you therefore need to be very precise and quick. The operator listens to your problem. Then he or she reads the information back to you. Next, the operator calls the emergency worker who is able to help you; if you are reporting a crime, such as a burglary, the operator will call the police department; if you report a fire the operator will call the nearest fire department; if you report a medical emergency the operator will call an ambulance service. Depending on the emergency, the police, a team of firefighters, or an emergency medical team will then be on their way to the scene.

Read the text and determine which of the following statements are true. If false, explain why.

  1. A 911 operator helps you in emergency situations.
  2. You should call 911 if you lose your glasses.
  3. All 911 operators are paid very well.
  4. Lives can depend on 911 operators.
  5. A 911 operator writes down your name and telephone number.
  6. The 911 operator will check to make sure the information is correct.
  7. The police department is not contacted if you report a fire.
  8. The operator contacts the hospital if you report a medical emergency.

items.altText: Difference between possessive adjectives and pronouns

items.content: You will need your Language Builder for more exercises. Your teacher will tell you which exercises you need to do for more practice. You will write these answers in your notebook.

content.body:
It's your money. It's yours.

  1. It's my bag. It's
  2. It's our car. It's
  3. They're her shoes. They're
  4. It's their house. It's
  5. They're your books. They're
  6. They're my glasses. They're
  7. It's his coat. It's

questions.label: Complete the sentences with mine/yours etc.

content.body:
It's their/ theirs problem, not our/ours.

  1. This is a nice camera. Is it your/yours?
  2. That's not my/mine umbrella. My/Mine is black.
  3. Whose books are these? Your/Yours or my/mine?
  4. Catherine is going out with her/hers friends this evening.
  5. My/Mine room is bigger than her/hers.
  6. They have two children, but I don't know their/theirs names.
  7. Can we use your washing machine? Our/Ours isn't working.

questions.label: Choose the right word

content.body:
I stayed at the house of my sister. my sister's house

  1. What is the name of this village? OK
  2. Do you like the colour of this coat?
  3. Do you have the phone number of Simon?
  4. The job of my brother is very interesting.
  5. Write your name at the top of the page.
  6. For me, the morning is the best part of the day.
  7. The favourite colour of Paula is blue.
  8. When is the birthday of your mother?
  9. The house of my parents isn't very big.
  10. The walls of this house are very thin.
  11. The car stopped at the end of the street.
  12. Are you going to the party of Silvia next week?
  13. The manager of the hotel is not here at the moment.

questions.label: Are these sentences OK? Change them where necessary.

content.body:
1. I read book and listened to music.
  2. I need money. I want to buy food.
  3. We met interesting people at the party.
  4. I'm going to open window to get fresh air.
  5. Rachel didn't eat much for lunch - only apple and bread.
  6. We live in big house. There's nice garden with beautiful trees.
  7. I'm going to make a table. First I need wood.
  8. Listen to me carefully. I'm going to give you advice.
  9. I want to make a list of things to do. I need paper and pen.

questions.label: Write a/an or some.

content.body: Please read the grammar instruction again.

1. I bought cheese, but I didn't buy bread.
  2. In the middle of the room there was a table and chairs.
  3. There aren't shops in this part of town.
  4. Gary and Alice don't have children.
  5. Do you have brothers or sisters?
  6. There are beautiful flowers in the garden.
  7. Do you know good hotels in London?
  8. 'Would you like tea?' 'Yes, please.'
  9. When we were on holiday, we visited interesting places.
  10. Don't buy rice. We don't need .

questions.label: Write some or any.

items.content:
Exercise 1:

Recipe

You are now going to write down the recipe of your favourite dish in English.
Think of the ingredients and the way it is prepared.
You should write at least 250 words.
Have a look at the following websites if you need help.

https://www.bbc.com/food/recipes

https://www.myrecipes.com/

Exercise 2:

My favourite cuisine
You are going to stay in a host family in America this summer.
You have started to write to them to introduce yourself. In their last email they asked you about your favourite cuisine and the food you like and do not like. Write an email back to tell them about your favourite cuisine and what food you like and don't like.
Also write what meal of the day you like most (breakfast? lunch? dinner?).
Write about 150 words.

Exercise 3:

English teacher
Één van de leraren Engels van jullie school vertrekt. Er moet een nieuwe Engelse leraar gezocht worden.
Schrijf samen met een klasgenoot een personeelsadvertentie voor een leraar Engels. De advertentie komt in de krant.

In de advertentie beschrijven jullie:

  • de school (grootte, aantal leerlingen, ligging, etc.);
  • wat jullie verwachten van de nieuwe Engelse docent;
  • hoe de sollicitant meer informatie over de baan kan krijgen;
  • hoe de sollicitant kan reageren op de advertentie;

items.title: Jobs, places of work and descriptions

items.content: You will have a conversation with a classmate about jobs, food and drinks.
You will have a conversation with your classmate about food and drinks.

Here you will learn about hobbies and sports.

You will learn how to talk about different hobbies and sports.

You will learn how to ask somebody for their preferences in hobbies and sports.

We will also pay attention to verbs of emotion + gerund form, the imperatives and going to for future plans/intentions and predictions.

You will read a short text and be able to understand the text.

You will have a conversation about hobbies and sports.
You are going to listen to audio fragments. While listening, do the exercises. Your teacher might print out the worksheet for you. Write the answers in your notebook.

You will need your Students' Book page 15 exercise 4.

You will need your Students' Book page 28 exercise 1.

You will need your Students' Book page 33 exercise 5.

Fishing exercise: Complete the sentences

I really ____________________ fishing is so popular.

It's one of the best-loved hobbies ____________________ world.

Anywhere there's a pond, a river a lake or sea, you see people fishing.

I've only been ____________________ and I thought it was boring. I didn't catch any fish.

Even if I had ____________________ , I don't think I ____________________ excited.

To me, sitting next to a river waiting for something ____________________ strange. I know lots of people who love fishing.

They ____________________ at four o'clock in the morning in the winter ____________________ freezing cold.

They say the best time to fish is before ____________________ up. I say they're crazy.

Big game fishing looks good. I like the idea ____________________ a boat near Hawaii looking for giant fish.

Dancing exercise: Complete the sentences

I have loved dancing ______________________ can remember. It was a part of my life when I was growing up ______________________ important to me now.

It has ______________________ best way to exercise.

What can be better than dancing to your favourite songs? I ______________________ clubs and discos. I can dance all night long.

I never get ______________________ . When I was small, I ______________________ school discos. I'd also dance at the parties my parents, friends and neighbours had.

I don't ______________________ ever stop dancing. I also love looking at dancing.

Ballet is beautiful. Dances ______________________ the world are beautiful.

I think ______________________ professional dancer must be a good one.

One thing that always amazes me is how much children love dancing.

I think dancing must be ______________________ .

Exercise 1: You will need your Students' Book page 28 exercise 2 and 3.

Exercise 2: You will need your Students' Book page 32 and 33 exercise 2 and 3.

Exercise 3:

Deepest underwater concert

The deepest concert was performed by Katie Melua (UK) and her band at 303 m (994 ft) below sea level, on Statoil's Troll a gas rig, off the coast of Bergen, Norway, on 1 October 2006.
Ms Melua performed two 30-minute concerts to an audience of 20 oilrig workers, each of whom had won the ticket to see the performance.

Largest collection of sick bags

Niek Vermeulen (Netherlands) has 6,016 airline sickness bags from 1,142 different airlines from more than 160 countries, as of 29 January 2010, which he has accumulated since the 1970s.

Bron: www.guinnessworldrecords.com

Beantwoord de vragen:

  1. Door wie werd het concert opgevoerd?
  2. In welk land vond het concert plaats?
  3. Hoe waren de aanwezigen aan een kaartje gekomen?
  4. Wat wordt door Niek Vermeulen verzameld?
  5. Uit hoeveel verschillende landen komen de spuugzakjes?
  6. Wanneer is hij begonnen met verzamelen?

Exercise 4:

Read the text then answer the questions.

Jacob the Great

Jacob hated finishing things almost as much as he loved starting them. As a result, he had got into a million hobbies and activities, but he never stuck with any of them long enough to get any good.

He begged his mother for months for a guitar so that he could play Black Eyed Peas songs to Angie, a girl whom he liked, but after he finally got one for Christmas, he found out that guitars doesn't play themselves. He took a few lessons, but strumming the strings hurt his fingers and he didn't like holding the pick, so now the five-hundred dollar guitar lives under his bed.

After reading an add in the back of one of his comic books, Jacob decided that he wanted a Wonder-Sweeper 5000 metal detector, so that he could find buried pirate treasures. So he mowed lawns all summer and didn't spend his money on ice-cream like his younger brother, Alex. He saved it all in a shoe box in his closet. Then he shovelled driveways all winter, and he didn't spend his money on candy and chips like his classmates. By the time spring came he had saved $200, and he purchased the Wonder-Sweeper 5000 metal detector. He beeped it around the park for a while, be he soon found out that no pirates had ever set sail in his neighborhood, and if they had they didn't leave any treasure. Even though he found a key ring, forty-seven cents, and all the bottle caps he could throw, he buried the metal detector in his closest.

Given Jacob's history with hobbies, it was no surprise that Jacob's father was reluctant to buy him a magician's kit for his birthday. "Geez, Jacob... You sure you wouldn't rather I got you more guitar lessons?" He suggested. Jacob was insistent. "Dad, you've got to get me the magician's kit. This time I'll stick with it for real. I promise! Come on, Dad," Jacob begged. Jacob's father sighed and then replied, "Oh, I don't know, Jacob. Things are awfully tight right now." But Jacob's father was reminded of his own youth long ago, when he quit from football and started karate practice before hardly getting his equipment dirty. So when Jacob's birthday came around, Jacob was both surprised and pleased to find the magician's kit that he had desired so badly with a big bright bow on it.

Jacob opened up the box and unwrapped the many parts in the kit. As he did so, he imagined sawing his pet cat in half and putting it back together to the amazement of his friends and family. He took the many fake coins, trick cards, and rope pieces of varying length on the kitchen table and imagined pulling rabbits out of his hat and turning them into pigeons with a mysterious puff of smoke. As Jacob continued pulling plastic thumbs, foam balls, and giant playing cards out of the magic kit, a commercial on the TV caught his attention. "Hey kids! Have you ever wanted to go to space? Experience what it's like to be an astronaut? Do you want to explore the universe? Well, now you can." As the commercial continued play, Jacob walked away from the magic kit on the kitchen table and stared at the TV screen longingly. "For only $195 you can go to space camp and live life like an astronaut for a whole weekend. Enroll now for a once in a life time experience." Jacob's cry rang throughout the house as he yelled, "MOM!" He now knew what his true purpose in life was.

Questions:

  1. What did Jacob get for Christmas?
  2. Why does Jacob stop playing the guitar?
  3. Why does Jacob decide that he wants a metal detector?
  4. Why doesn't Jacob's father want to get him the magician's kit for his birthday?
  5. What was Jacob's reaction to this birthday present?
  6. What distracts Jacob from the magician's kit?
You will need your Language Builder for more exercises. Your teacher will tell you which exercises you need to do for more practice. You will write these answers in your notebook.

  15. I'm trying . (work) Please stop (talk)

items.title: Exercise 4: Imperative exercises
items.description: Go to this link and do all six exercises online. Make a screenshot to show your teacher you have done all six exercises.

items.content:
Exercise 1:

You are on holiday in England with your family. All of you like outdoor activities. You want to 'go ape'. Have a look at the following website to see what that means. Write and email to make a reservation for your family. Mention the day, time, and ask if you can pay by creditcard. Start and end your email in an appropriate way.

Exercise 2:

Your school has organised an exchange programme with an Italian school.

You will sleep at the house of an Italian student in Rome.

  • Write an email to introduce yourself.
  • Write about yourself, your hobbies and what you like to do in your free time.
  • Propose an activity you want to do in Rome and ask if the exchange student likes this activity.
  • Close your email by saying you really look forward to going to Rome.

You will have a conversation with a classmate about hobbies and sports.

Exercise 1:

Persoon A

Persoon B

Groet.

Groet netjes terug.

Vraag of de ander een hobby heeft.

Vertel welke hobby jij hebt. Zeg dat je er plezier in hebt.

Zeg dat je drie keer per week traint. Vraag de ander hoeveel hij/zij traint.

Zeg dat je elke dag traint. Zeg dat je daar plezier in hebt.

Stel een zelfbedachte vraag passend bij het thema.

Geef antwoord.

Stel een zelf bedachte vraag passend bij het thema.

Geef antwoord.

Beëindig het gesprek.

Reageer en sluit af.

Change roles and do the exercise again.

Exercise 2:

Have a conversation with your classmate and discuss the following items:

  • Whether you like them or not
  • How long you have had these hobbies for
  • Who joins you in these hobbies
  • How many times a week you spend time on this hobby
  • What your hobbies were in the past

Here you will learn about housing and places.

You will learn how to talk about different housing and places.

You will learn how to ask somebody to describe their housing and preferences in places.

We will also pay attention to comparatives and superlatives, the use of much and many, the use of few and little, countable and uncountable nouns and the past simple (onvoltooid verleden tijd).

You will read a short text and be able to understand the text.

You will have a conversation about housing and places.

  3. Oxford Street is a famous street for [drinking tea / eating / shopping].

Exercise : Complete the sentences while listening

In the USA, ______________________ apartments; in the UK they're called flats.

They are a ______________________ . I don't particularly like them.

I don't think it's good for so many people to ______________________ together.

It's not good for people to live ______________________ each other.

I don't understand how people can live ______________________ second floor.

It's not natural to live in the sky. The thing ______________________ about apartments are the lifts (Americans say elevator) and ______________________ no garden.

More and more people are moving into apartments. This ______________________ with overcrowding.

There aren't enough spaces ______________________ car, there's nowhere to throw your rubbish and you have ______________________ to reach your floor.

Give me a little house with a little garden any day.

Exercise 1: Read the text then answer the questions

Aunt Helen's house

I'm going to tell you about my Aunt Helen's house. It's not her main house, that's in the city. No, this house is by the lake. There was a small town by the lake called Miller's Ford, but all the people moved away when the fishing and mining stopped about sixty years ago. But the houses stayed, of course. My Aunt Helen uses that house as a vacation home and she goes there for a few weeks every year to relax.

But staying in that house isn't a relaxing experience. I think the house is haunted! I think there's a ghost there from many many years ago. Helen says I'm silly and that I've got an over-active imagination. But there are many things that happen in that house that cannot be easily explained.

One day, shortly after getting up, I went to find my Aunt Helen to say "good morning" and I heard her talking in a room that she usually never uses. I think it used to be the nursery of the house when Miller's Ford was a busy town in the 19th Century. I listened at the door and could hear Helen reading something out, or perhaps she was dictating a letter. I couldn't hear any other person in the room with her so it wasn't a normal conversation. I didn't want to disturb my aunt, so I went back downstairs and went to make breakfast in the kitchen, which I ate on the porch that overlooked the lake. It was a beautiful sunny morning. Half an hour later, I heard my aunt's car arriving. She had been to the local store to buy some bread and milk. I couldn't believe it!

"What are you looking so shocked for?" she asked me.

"I thought you were in the old nursery, working on your letters, Auntie," I replied.

"I never go in that room," she said. "I haven't been in that room for fifteen years."

A few other things like that happened over the next few visits I made to that house and I grew to dislike it very much. Then, one day in my local library, I found a story in an old newspaper with the title "The Constant Babysitter". The story was that a baby had died in one of the houses by the lake at Miller's Ford and the babysitter was blamed, a woman of 37 who was a family friend and had offered to look after the baby. But she spent all her time in the kitchen writing her letters and didn't know that someone had climbed in the baby's window and taken her. The baby was never found. The woman killed herself through depression after the baby's disappearance and local people then said her ghost stayed very close to where the baby was left by the parents - in the nursery.

I never went back to that house, despite my Aunt Helen's many invitations.

Questions:

  1. Welke informatie krijg je in de eerste alinea over het huis van tante Helen?
  2. Wat vind de verteller van het verblijf in het huis van tante Helen?
  3. Wat was Miller's Ford in de negentiende eeuw?
  4. In welke kamer dacht de verteller tante Helen te horen praten?
  5. Waarom denkt de verteller dat er een spook in het huis is?
  6. Why did the people leave Miller's Ford?
  7. Why was the narrator looking for Aunt Helen?
  8. Why did the narrator think it wasn't a "normal conversation"?
  9. What did Aunt Helen say about the nursery?
  10. Who took the baby in the story?

items.content:
Exercise 1: Make a poster

My future (futuristic) dream house.
Make a poster with a design of your future (futuristic) dream house. You are free to design your house the way you like it, but it must be "green". Sources that may be of use when designing your future (futuristic) dream house are
'Grand designs' and 'World's greenest homes' (both to be found on Youtube).

The poster should include / point out:

  • A floor plan of your future (futuristic) dream house: ground floor, first floor (second floor) and garden. Names of the rooms should be written in them. You can use floorplanner.com to help you planning your space if you like.
  • Images of what the various rooms will look like (3 pieces of furniture for each room included).
    You can use www.italiadesigns.co.uk or www.designfurniture.com.au to look for pieces of furniture to 'glue' into your rooms.
  • The eco friendly devices / installations in your house.
  • The location of your future (futuristic) dream house.
  • Three main rules to be followed in your future (futuristic) dream house.

Who do you think designed the best house in your class?
Who designed the most eccentric house?
Who designed the most eco-friendly house?

Exercise 2: Write an email

You have found a wonderful house you'd like to swap with during the summer.
Send an email to the owner of the house (contact person).

Write:

  • who you are
  • that you read his advertisement on the site
  • who you will be travelling with
  • what you like about his / her house
  • what kind of house you have (location, attractions near your house, number of rooms, names of rooms).
    Look at the descriptions on www.lovehomeswap.comif you need inspiration
  • when you want to swap homes
  • that you look forward to hearing from him / her soon

Level: intermediate

Topical news lessons at elementary level with worksheets. Each worksheet contains vocabulary, speaking and grammar work as well as reading practice. The topics are all very different. Your teacher might print these worksheets for you.

Let's put on our thinking caps!

items.title: Australia suffers from record breaking high temperatures
Bob Dylan wins the Nobel Prize for Literature
Chile bans the use of disposable plastic bags
Elizabeth II celebrates 65 years as British queen
Fifty-eight die in shooting in Las Vegas
Hurricane Irma the worst Atlantic storm ever
Is it safe to eat eggs?
Jungle refugee camp in Calais closed
Tiger kills zookeeper at British zoo
Train travels backwards without an engine
Woman survives after ten hours in the sea

items.content: Extra challenge: The following news lessons are a bit more difficult.

items.title: Facebook fake review factories uncovered by investigation
Finland is the happiest country in the world
How a 12-year-old ran away to Bali
Huge reduction in meat-eating essential to avoid climate breakdown
Pupils react to French phone ban
Social media spying is turning us into a stalking society

items.content:
Learning by doing & in context

Goal of a webquest: to instill in learners the capacity to navigate the Internet with a clear task in mind, retrieve data from multiple resources and use them to produce a final product of value.

We hope to inspire our students to see richer thematic relationships exploring web resources and to facilitate a contribution to the real world of learning.

HOW TO:

- download the webquest

- put the document in your OneDrive

- then start on the webquest
Study these verbs by heart

Infinitive

 Past simple (onvoltooid verleden tijd) Past Participle (voltooid deelwoord)
be was/ were been/ gone
become became become
begin began begun
break broke broken
bring brought brought
burn burnt burnt
buy bought bought
catch caught caught
choose chose chosen
come came come
cost cost cost
do did done
dream dreamt dreamt
drink drank drunk
drive drove driven
eat ate eaten
fall fell fallen
feel felt felt
find found found
fly flew flown
forget forgot forgotten
get got got
give gave given
go went gone
have had had
hear heard heard
hit hit hit
hurt hurt hurt
keep kept kept
know knew known
learn learnt learnt
leave left left
lose lost lost
make made made
meet met met
pay paid paid
put put put
read read read
ride rode ridden
ring rang rung
run ran run
say said said
see saw seen
sell sold sold
send sent sent
shine shone shone
sing sang sung
sit sat sat
sleep slept slept
speak spoke spoken
spend spent spent
stand stood stood
sting stung stung
swim swam swum
take took taken
teach taught taught
tear tore torn
tell told told
think thought thought
throw threw thrown
understand understood understood
wake woke woken
wear wore worn
win won won
write wrote written

Being able to use a dictionary properly is very important in learning a language. Here are six worksheets to help you learn how to do this properly.

You will need your dictionary for these exercises.

Your teacher might print out these worksheets for you.
